meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Senate Leaders Agree To Revive Migrant Bill Senate Democratic and Republican leaders said they had agreed on a way to revive a comprehensive immigration bill that had been pulled off the Senate floor seven days ago. It is expected to return to the floor this month.
PAGE A23

Libby Going to Prison Soon I. Lewis Libby Jr., once one of the most powerful men in government, will have to begin serving his 30-month prison sentence shortly, even before his appeals are exhausted, a judge in Washington ruled.
PAGE A20
Vote Preserves Gay Marriage Same-sex marriage will continue to be legal in Massachusetts, after a proposed amendment defining marriage was rejected.
PAGE A16
Kurt Waldheim Is Dead The former United Nations secretary general and president of Austria, whose career was eroded when his hidden work with the Nazis was exposed, was 88.
PAGE B7

Squad Cars Move Beyond the Wail In New York police cars, activating the siren is not just a matter of flipping a switch. The cars have five tones, and the department is testing a sixth: the Rumbler, which blasts low-frequency vibrations in all directions.
PAGE B1

Report on Student Lending Gifts and payoffs to universities and their officials by student lenders were far more pervasive than has been disclosed and in some cases were demanded by university officials themselves, according to a Senate report.
PAGE A21

Spurs Sweep Cavaliers Manu Ginóbili scored 27 points and Tony Parker added 24 to lead the San Antonio Spurs to an 83-82 victory against the Cleveland Cavaliers. The win gave the Spurs their fourth N.B.A. title.
SPORTSFRIDAY, PAGE D6
Concussions in the N.F.L. Justin Strzelczyk, a deceased former N.F.L. lineman, had brain damage that could be linked to injuries he sustained on the field.
PAGE D1

A Tax Move on Equity Firms Two United States senators have introduced legislation that could significantly increase taxes on private equity firms and hedge funds that become publicly traded companies.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

McCartney, Up Close Yes, that was Paul McCartney playing an unadvertised 90-minute set at a 700-person room in Manhattan. The show, promoting a new album, ''Memory Almost Full,'' mixed five new works with several from his older Beatles catalog. A review by Ben Ratliff.
WEEKEND, PAGE E5
